channel.title: Comments on: Waterfall plots with changing color

item.title: By: Varun
item.dc:creator: Varun
item.description:
Hi,
Is it possible to change the background colour of a graph such that the interior of the graph (within the axes) is of one colour, and the exterior (outside the axes) is of another colour?
Thanks!
item.content:encoded:
Hi,

Is it possible to change the background colour of a graph such that the interior of the graph (within the axes) is of one colour, and the exterior (outside the axes) is of another colour?

Thanks!

item.title: By: Hanno
item.dc:creator: Hanno
item.description: Nice example but I've had a hard time to reproduce it. In both version 5.0.4 and 5.0.6 the "border" keyword for the fill style appears to be ignored when the y1=-360 is set. So all you get is white on white. Couldn't find a fix for but it works in 5.0.0 so I just used the older version.
item.content:encoded: Nice example but I’ve had a hard time to reproduce it. In both version 5.0.4 and 5.0.6 the “border” keyword for the fill style appears to be ignored when the y1=-360 is set. So all you get is white on white. Couldn’t find a fix for but it works in 5.0.0 so I just used the older version.

item.title: By: hagen
item.dc:creator: hagen
item.description: Hi, thanks, iteration is indeed only possible with integer values. I changed the post accordingly.
item.content:encoded: Hi, thanks, iteration is indeed only possible with integer values. I changed the post accordingly.

item.title: By: Thales Sabino
item.dc:creator: Thales Sabino
item.description:
I was looking for a way to use the plot for command with decimals. I found this page but I wasn't able to produce a result with this command
plot for [h=0:1:0.1] sin(x*h)
So I asked in the StackOverflow and a nice gentleman tells me that the increment of the for loop in gnuplot is "cast" to integer. So in your example, the increment is actually -2.
If you want to check the question here is the link: http://stackoverflow.com/questions/33244494/gnuplot-for-loop-with-increment-smaller-then-1
Also in the gnuplot manual, page 98, it is written the following:
"The iteration variable (’i’ in this example) is treated as an integer, and may be used more than once."
Hope this helps!
item.content:encoded:
I was looking for a way to use the plot for command with decimals. I found this page but I wasn’t able to produce a result with this command

plot for [h=0:1:0.1] sin(x*h)

So I asked in the StackOverflow and a nice gentleman tells me that the increment of the for loop in gnuplot is “cast” to integer. So in your example, the increment is actually -2.

If you want to check the question here is the link: http://stackoverflow.com/questions/33244494/gnuplot-for-loop-with-increment-smaller-then-1

Also in the gnuplot manual, page 98, it is written the following:

“The iteration variable (’i’ in this example) is treated as an integer, and may be used more than once.”

Hope this helps!

item.title: By: Cheshire Cat
item.dc:creator: Cheshire Cat
item.description: Dude, it's great. You can be sure i'll use it - you just got a part in visualisation of Bose-Einstein condensate simulations.
item.content:encoded: Dude, it’s great. You can be sure i’ll use it – you just got a part in visualisation of Bose-Einstein condensate simulations.

item.title: By: Adrian

item.content:encoded: Looks great, Exactly what I need. Thansk for your advice and help.
